bestBHT.bht: Jesus, in his prayer to the Father, acknowledges the disciples as a gift from the Father Himself. They have kept the word of the Father and have walked in His commandments. Jesus has manifested the name of the Father, revealing His character and attributes to the disciples. The Father, in His electing grace, has chosen and given the disciples to Christ, and Jesus in turn has manifested the Father's name to them. Ultimately, the disciples are a product of the Father's purpose and providence, given to Christ to carry out His divine plan.

Henry Alford: Thy Name of FATHER, which was so constantly on the lips of our Lord;—and which derived its living meaning and power from His teaching.
The Father gave them to Christ, by leading them to Christ.
They have kept thy word—walked in the path of Thy commandments.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: From praying for Himself He now comes to pray for His disciples.
Thy name—His whole character towards mankind.
Albert Barnes: Jesus had made known his character, his law, his will, his plan of mercy - or, in other words, he had revealed God to them.
God gave them to him in his purpose. He gave them by his providence.
God has a right to the services of all; and he has a right to appoint us to any labor, however humble, or hazardous, or wearisome, where we may promote his glory and honor his name.
John Calvin: Not all to whom the doctrine is exhibited are truly and efficaciously taught, but only those whose minds are enlightened.
The elect always belonged to God. God therefore distinguishes them from the reprobate, not by faith, or by any merit, but by pure grace.
The word of God flows out to the reprobate, but it takes root in the elect, and hence they are said to keep it.
Philip Schaff: That 'word' had been especially the 'name' of God, His name as 'Father,' including His character, His attributes, His saving will as revealed in Jesus.
They had been given to the Son by the Father 'out of the world;' that is, they were no longer in the world as the element of their existence.
In the Word of God they have God's word in them. How completely are they put into the position of Him who is now 'going away'!
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus regards the apostles as the Father's gift to him."
Jesus claims loyalty and fidelity in these men with the one exception of Judas.
He does not claim perfection for them, but they have at least held on to the message of the Father in spite of doubt and wavering.
John Gill: The name of twelve letters, Galatinus pretends, is Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, the words for which in the Hebrew language consist of twelve letters; and that of forty two letters he makes to be this, the Father God, the Son God, the Holy Ghost God, yet there are not three Gods, but one God; or thus, the Father God, the Son God, the Holy Ghost God, three in one, one in three; the Hebrew words for which contain forty two letters.

Christ himself, or his name Jesus, God by the angel gave him, and in whose name there is salvation, and no other can be thought to be meant; and which, as it was manifested to his disciples, so it is to all whom God has chosen and given to Christ.

The persons given were not the Father's merely by creation; for so others are his also; nor would they be peculiarly his, for they are the son's likewise in this sense; but they are his by electing grace, which is the peculiar act of the Father in Christ, and is unto salvation by him, through the sanctification of the Spirit.
John Wesley: I have manifested thy name — All thy attributes; and in particular thy paternal relation to believers."
They were thine — By creation, and by descent from Abraham."
And thou hast given them me — By giving them faith in what I have spoken.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, in his prayer to the Father, acknowledges the disciples as a gift from the Father Himself. They have kept the word of the Father and have walked in His commandments, despite their doubts and wavering. Jesus has manifested the name of the Father, revealing His character and attributes to the disciples. The disciples belong to the Father, being His by creation and descent from Abraham. Jesus claims loyalty and fidelity in these men, and prays for them with the exception of Judas. The Father, in His electing grace, has chosen and given the disciples to Christ, and Jesus in turn has manifested the Father's name to them. Ultimately, the disciples are a product of the Father's purpose and providence, given to Christ to carry out His divine plan of redemption.

Jesus, in his prayer to the Father, acknowledges the disciples as a gift from the Father Himself. They have kept the word of the Father and have walked in His commandments. Jesus has manifested the name of the Father, revealing His character and attributes to the disciples. The Father, in His electing grace, has chosen and given the disciples to Christ, and Jesus in turn has manifested the Father's name to them. Ultimately, the disciples are a product of the Father's purpose and providence, given to Christ to carry out His divine plan.

In His prayer, Jesus recognizes the disciples as a precious gift from the Father, affirming their faithful adherence to God's Word. Jesus has made known the Father's name, revealing His character and attributes to the disciples. They belong to the Father, by creation and descent. The Father, in His electing grace, has chosen and bestowed the disciples upon Christ. Through this divine exchange, the Father's purpose is carried out, as Jesus manifests the Father's name and plan to the disciples.

In His prayer, Jesus acknowledges the disciples as a gift from the Father Himself. They have kept the word of the Father and walked in His commandments. Jesus has manifested the name of the Father, revealing His character to the disciples. The disciples belong to the Father, by creation and descent. The Father, in His electing grace, has chosen and given the disciples to Christ. Through this divine exchange, the Father's purpose is fulfilled as Jesus manifests the Father's name and plan to the disciples.

In His prayer, Jesus acknowledges the disciples as a precious gift from the Father Himself. They have faithfully kept the Father's word and followed His commandments. Jesus has manifested the full character of the Father to them, revealing His attributes and His saving will. The disciples belong to the Father, chosen by His electing grace. Jesus claims their loyalty and fidelity, except for Judas, and prays for them. Through this divine exchange, the Father's purpose and plan are revealed as Jesus manifests His name to the disciples.
